channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Water Pricing, Not Engineering, Will Ease Looming Water Shortages
item.description: In trying to engineer their way out of water scarcity, Brazil’s leaders are repeating mistakes made by their American counterparts.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT MOORE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: France Gives In to the Hashtag
item.description: The chief guardian of the French language bows to the demands of the computer age.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM ALEXANDER

item.title: Editors and Executives of News Website Malaysian Insider Are Arrested
item.description: Critics call the detention of five people from the publication, over an article about a proposal to allow strict Islamic law, an assault on press freedom.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Singapore Arrests Teenager Over Video Critical of Lee Kuan Yew
item.description: The arrest came on Sunday as a state funeral for Mr. Lee, the founding father who died last week, was attended by world leaders and dignitaries.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Mourners lined the streets on Sunday to watch the state funeral procession for Lee Kuan Yew, the founding father of Singapore.

item.title: Preliminary Nuclear Deal Appears Close, but Tough Issues May Wait
item.description: Any accord that is reached to limit Iran’s nuclear program will be, by design, an interim instrument, more an outline than a final agreement.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Foreign ministers and delegates on Tuesday in Lausanne, Switzerland, ahead of a deadline on negotiations to limit Iran’s nuclear program.

item.title: Witnesses, Who Say Police Killed Activist, Are to Be Charged in Egypt
item.description: Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Our Man in Tehran — Episode 2: The Martyr’s Daughter
item.description: A supporter of Iran’s Islamic Revolution, Najiyeh Allahdad, sees it as her duty to speak out when the government fails to live up to the ideals for which her father fought and died.
item.dc:creator: As told to THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: South Korea Picks Contractor to Develop New Jet Fighter
item.description: Korea Aerospace Industries has been selected for the $7.7 billion project and will receive technological help from Lockheed Martin.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Korea Aerospace Industries already builds the FA-50, a lightweight fighter it exports to the Philippines and has sold to the South Korean Air Force.

item.title: Suspect’s Request to Testify Adds Wrinkle to Litvinenko Inquiry
item.description: The judge set July 27 as the date for testimony by Dmitri V. Kovtun, who demanded a chance to clear his name and exonerate the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned with radioactive polonium 210, in London in 2004.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Yemen Evacuation Shows Chinese Navy’s Growing Role
item.description: The Chinese ambassador to Yemen described the evacuation of nearly 600 people as “a significant practice of major power diplomacy with Chinese characteristics.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Chinese preparing to leave Yemen from the western port city of Al Hudaydah on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Is Urged to Confront Its Own History
item.description: China’s insistence that Japan “face history” is raising uncomfortable questions about Beijing’s own practice of suppressing historical truths about trespasses domestic and abroad.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: At center, Son Sen, the Khmer Rouge defense minister, with Chinese advisers in 1977.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Adam Fisk on Evading Internet Censorship in China
item.description: The lead developer of Lantern, a censorship-evading tool, discusses how it works and how it has reacted to the new measures by Chinese Internet regulators.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Adam Fisk, lead developer of Lantern.

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Old Land Mines Kill Six
item.description: Iranian state television said two land mines left over from the 1980s Iran-Iraq war killed six people on Monday, five of them Iranian border guards and the other a female shepherd.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nigeria’s Presidential Race Stretches to Another Day
item.description: The incumbent president is facing a tough challenge as voting results poured in from distant states in this crowded and chaotic land.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiters at a nightclub on the outskirts of Kano, Nigeria, watched the counting of votes on television Monday.

item.title: An Anxious Wait in Syrian City Held by Insurgents
item.description: Government forces were routed from Idlib, a provincial capital in the country’s north.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A fighter carried a Nusra Front brigade flag in Idlib, Syria, on Sunday. A coalition of Islamic insurgents controls the city.

item.title: News Analysis: Role of Illness in Germanwings Crash Raises Worry About Stigma
item.description: The intense focus on the co-pilot’s mental illness has raised concerns that it could stigmatize mentally ill people and make it harder to identify troubled workers.
item.dc:creator: ERICA GOODE

item.title: Obama, Last Election Behind Him, Plans First Visit as President to Kenya
item.description: President Obama will travel to Kenya in July to co-host a forum on entrepreneurship as part of an effort to support economic development in Africa.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Witnesses, Who Say Police Killed Activist, Are to Be Charged in Egypt
item.description: Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: As U.S. and Iran Seek Nuclear Deal, Saudi Arabia Makes Its Own Moves
item.description: The talks themselves are already changing the dynamics of regional politics as Saudi Arabia, Iran’s chief regional rival, acts against Iranian-backed groups in Yemen, Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A soldier searched a house in Tikrit, Iraq, where ISIS appears to have a greater presence than initially thought.

item.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
item.description: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KULISH and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Members of the search team worked Monday at the crash site of the Germanwings Airbus A320. Clouds grounded helicopters, and search teams and investigators had to hike up on foot.
